name: Henry VIII
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Henry VII and Elizabeth of York (York), were third cousins. His inbreeding rate primarily reflects the genetic implications of his first marriage to Catherine of Aragon (Trastámara), his deceased brother's wife, a union of close affinity. The rate is calculated for their child, Mary I.
titles: King of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, Lord of Ireland 🇮🇪, later King of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: Edward VI
inbreeding_explanation: As the son of Henry VIII, he inherited a baseline of inbreeding. His mother, Jane Seymour (Seymour), was Henry's third cousin. Their union was less genetically close than Henry's previous marriages, resulting in a lower inbreeding rate for their son compared to his half-sisters.
titles: King of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, King of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: Mary I
inbreeding_explanation: Her parents, Henry VIII of England and his first wife, Catherine of Aragon (Trastámara), were third cousins once removed, both descending from John of Gaunt (Lancaster). The high rate reflects the compounded inheritance from a web of aristocratic English and Spanish intermarriages.
titles: Queen of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, Queen of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: Elizabeth I
inbreeding_explanation: Her parents were Henry VIII and his second wife, Anne Boleyn (Boleyn). The high rate is a reflection of the complex web of relations in the English aristocracy; Anne's mother was a Howard, a family with close and repeated intermarriages with royalty, which concentrated the genetic pool passed to Elizabeth.
titles: Queen of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, Queen of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: James I
inbreeding_explanation: His high rate is due to his parents, Mary, Queen of Scots, and Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, being closely related through multiple lines. They were primarily half-first cousins, as both descended from their shared grandmother, Margaret Tudor (Tudor). This relationship was strengthened by their more distant shared Stuart ancestry.
titles: King of Scots 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿, King of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, King of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: Charles I
inbreeding_explanation: His father was James I. His mother, Anne of Denmark (Oldenburg), was not a close relative, but she was herself the product of a first-cousin marriage. Charles I therefore inherited a significant genetic load from both his father's direct inbreeding and his mother's own inherited inbreeding.
titles: King of England 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿, King of Scots 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿, King of Ireland 🇮🇪

name: Louis XIII

name: Louis XIV
inbreeding_explanation: His significant inbreeding comes from his parents, Louis XIII of France and Anne of Austria (Habsburg), who were double first cousins. This was because his paternal grandfather and maternal grandmother were siblings, and his paternal grandmother and maternal grandfather were also siblings. This perfectly symmetrical, close-family union is the source of his high inbreeding rate.
titles: King of France 🇫🇷

name: Louis XV
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Louis, Duke of Burgundy, and Marie Adélaïde of Savoy (Savoy), were second cousins. The inbreeding score is primarily a reflection of the accumulated intermarriages from previous generations, particularly that of his paternal grandparents who were first cousins.
titles: King of France 🇫🇷

children.name: Louise Élisabeth
children.title: Princess of France, Duchess Consort of Parma

name: Louis XVI
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Louis, Dauphin of France, and Maria Josepha of Saxony (Wettin), were second cousins. This relatively distant relation still produced a notable inbreeding rate due to the dense web of shared ancestry between the Bourbon, Habsburg, and other German royal lines in prior generations.
titles: King of France 🇫🇷

name: Louis XVIII
inbreeding_explanation: As the brother of Louis XVI, he shares the exact same parentage and inherited inbreeding from the dense ancestral connections between the great royal houses of Europe.
titles: King of France 🇫🇷

name: Charles X
inbreeding_explanation: The youngest brother of Louis XVI and Louis XVIII, he has an identical genetic inheritance, reflecting the established pattern of intermarriage within the Bourbon family and their relatives.
titles: King of France 🇫🇷

name: Louis Philippe I Orléans
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans, and Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon, were second cousins. His rate is particularly high for a second-cousin union because both of his grandmothers were granddaughters of a Habsburg emperor, and his grandfathers also shared recent common ancestors.
titles: King of the French 🇫🇷

father.name: Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans

spouses.name: Maria Amalia of Naples and Sicily

name: Philip V
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Louis, Grand Dauphin of France, and Maria Anna Victoria of Bavaria (Wittelsbach), were first cousins. His already high rate was significantly elevated because his paternal grandparents, King Louis XIV of France and Maria Theresa of Spain (Habsburg), were themselves double first cousins, carrying forward an immense pre-existing genetic load.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Ferdinand VI
inbreeding_explanation: As the son of Philip V, he inherited a significant baseline of inbreeding from his father's side. His mother, Maria Luisa of Savoy (Savoy), introduced a less-related line, keeping his own rate from escalating further.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Charles IV
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Charles III of Spain and Maria Amalia of Saxony (Wettin), were first cousins once removed. This union's high rate is compounded by the fact that his paternal grandmother was a Bourbon and his maternal grandmother was a Habsburg, representing the continued consolidation of these two dominant houses.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Ferdinand VII
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Charles IV of Spain and Maria Luisa of Parma (Bourbon-Parma), were first cousins. The high rate comes from the fact that his four grandparents were all direct descendants of King Louis XIV of France (Bourbon), making for an extremely narrow pool of recent ancestors.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Isabella II
inbreeding_explanation: Her parentage is a complex web of close relations. Her mother, Maria Christina of the Two Sicilies (Bourbon-Two Sicilies), was her father Ferdinand VII's niece. Furthermore, her paternal grandparents and maternal grandparents were both pairs of first cousins, creating multiple layers of inbreeding.
titles: Queen of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Alfonso XII
inbreeding_explanation: His extreme rate stems from his parents being double first cousins. His mother, Queen Isabella II, and his officially recognized father, Francis, Duke of Cádiz, were the children of two brothers from the Spanish Bourbon line. This was severely compounded by the fact that his maternal grandmother was also his paternal grandfather's sister.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Alfonso XIII
inbreeding_explanation: His father, Alfonso XII, was one of the most inbred monarchs in history. While his mother, Maria Christina of Austria (Habsburg-Lorraine), came from a less intertwined branch of the Habsburgs, he still inherited a significant genetic load.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

mother.name: Princess Beatrice of the United Kingdom

name: Juan Carlos I
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona, and Princess María de las Mercedes of Bourbon-Two Sicilies (Bourbon-Two Sicilies), were second cousins. However, both of their family trees were so saturated with prior unions of first cousins that their marriage produced an exceptionally high coefficient of inbreeding.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Felipe VI

His rate is lower than his father's because his mother, Queen Sofía of Greece and Denmark (Glücksburg), hailed from a different royal line, introducing more genetic diversity than had been seen in the Spanish monarchy for centuries.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸

name: Matthias I

titles: Holy Roman Emperor 🇩🇪, King of Bohemia 🇨🇿, King of Hungary 🇭🇺, Archduke of Austria 🇦🇹

name: Ferdinand II

name: Charles II
inbreeding_explanation: His genetic collapse was the result of generations of Habsburg inbreeding. His own parents' marriage was between uncle and niece, Philip IV of Spain and Mariana of Austria. Looking back just one more generation, his maternal grandparents were first cousins. This relentless intermarriage meant that while a person normally has eight unique great-grandparents, Charles II effectively only had four. The result was a family tree so narrow that every one of his great-grandparents, regardless of the branch, was a descendant of the same ancestral couple from over a century and a half prior: Joanna (Trastámara) and Philip I of Castile (Habsburg). This produced a final coefficient of inbreeding higher than that of a child from a direct brother-sister union.
titles: King of Spain 🇪🇸, King of Naples 🇮🇹, King of Sicily 🇮🇹, Duke of Milan 🇮🇹

name: Frederick III
inbreeding_explanation: His high rate is due to his parents being second cousins, but from extremely interrelated families. His paternal grandmother and maternal grandfather were siblings, creating a close genetic link that significantly elevated his inherited inbreeding.
titles: German Emperor 🇩🇪, King of Prussia 🇩🇪

children.name: Charlotte

name: Wilhelm II
inbreeding_explanation: He was the son of a marriage between close relatives, Frederick III of Prussia and Victoria (Hanover), Princess Royal. His high rate is a product of his parents being second cousins, but his paternal and maternal grandmothers also being first cousins.
titles: German Emperor 🇩🇪, King of Prussia 🇩🇪

children.name: Victoria Louise
children.title: Princess of Prussia, Duchess of Brunswick

name: George V
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, King Edward VII (Saxe-Coburg and Gotha) and Queen Alexandra of Denmark (Glücksburg), were second cousins once removed. The high inbreeding rate listed here reflects the genetic legacy passed to his children, which was a result of his own marriage to his second cousin, Princess Mary of Teck (Württemberg), further concentrating the descendants of Queen Victoria (Hanover).
titles: King of the United Kingdom 🇬🇧, Emperor of India 🇮🇳

name: Edward VIII
inbreeding_explanation: As the son of George V and Queen Mary (Württemberg), who were second cousins, he was born with a significant inbreeding rate from a union that further concentrated the descendants of their shared great-grandmother, Queen Victoria (Hanover).
titles: King of the United Kingdom 🇬🇧, Emperor of India 🇮🇳

name: George VI
inbreeding_explanation: The brother of Edward VIII, he shares the same parentage and an identical inbreeding rate, born from the union of second cousins King George V and Queen Mary (Württemberg).
titles: King of the United Kingdom 🇬🇧, Emperor of India 🇮🇳, Head of the Commonwealth

name: Elizabeth II
titles: Queen of the United Kingdom 🇬🇧, Head of the Commonwealth

father.name: Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark

name: Charles III
inbreeding_explanation: His parents, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip (Glücksburg), Duke of Edinburgh, were second cousins once removed through their shared descent from King Christian IX (Glücksburg) of Denmark, and also third cousins through their shared descent from Queen Victoria (Hanover).
titles: King of the United Kingdom 🇬🇧, Head of the Commonwealth
